keyATM Covariates

Source: vignettes/pkgdown_files/keyATM_cov.Rmd
keyATM_cov.Rmd

Preparing documents and covariates

Please read Preparation for the reading of documents and creating a list of keywords. We use bills data we prapared (documents and keywords).

library(keyATM)
library(quanteda)

data(keyATM_data_bills)
bills_keywords <- keyATM_data_bills$keywords
bills_dfm <- keyATM_data_bills$doc_dfm  # quanteda dfm object
keyATM_docs <- keyATM_read(bills_dfm)

For the covariate data, we use the dummy variable which takes one if the bill is proposesd by the Republican party and zero otherwise (Adler and Wilkerson 2018). keyATM takes matrix or data.frame (tibble) type covariates data. If you have \(D\) documents and \(M\) covariates, the matrix should be \(D \times M\). In this example, we have a dummy variable that indicates party identification.

bills_cov <- keyATM_data_bills$cov # dummy variable indicating the party proposed the bill
dim(bills_cov)  # We have 140 documents and a single covariate for each document
## [1] 140   1
table(bills_cov) # this is a binary indicator
## bills_cov
##  0  1 
## 54 86

Please make sure that the order of covariates is the same as the order of documents. The easiest way to match the order and the dimension of covariats with the documents is to use the docvars argument in quanteda when you construct a corpus object.

CORPUS <- corpus(raw_docs, text_field = "text", docvars = COVARIATES)
[...preprocess and make a dfm object...]
covariates <- docvars(DFM_OBJECT)

Fitting the model

out <- keyATM(
              docs              = keyATM_docs,                            # text input
              no_keyword_topics = 3,                                      # number of topics without keywords
              keywords          = bills_keywords,                         # keywords (a list)
              model             = "covariates",                           # select the model
              model_settings    = list(covariates_data    = bills_cov,    # covariate data
                                       covariates_formula = ~ RepParty,   # formula to fit covarite
                                       mh_use             = FALSE),       # use Metloporis Hastings
              options           = list(seed = 250)
             )

The covariates_formula takes the same form of a formula for model.matrix() function. You do not need to specify the left hand side of the formula. The default number of iterations is 1500. Please check this page for available options.

Saving the model

Once you fit the model, you can save the model with save() for replication. This is the same as the Base model.

Checking top words

top_words(out)
##      1_Education     2_Law     3_Health        4_Drug       Other_1     Other_2
## 1  education [✓]    action   public [✓]      drug [✓]       law [2]     project

Reference

Adler, E Scott and John Wilkerson. 2018. ``Congressional bills project.'' NSF 880066 and 0080061:213–227.
